citation.article-title: Methanogenium marinum sp. nov., a H2-using methanogen from Skan Bay, Alaska, and kinetics of H2 utilization.

p.s: Description of Methanogenium marinum sp. nov.
Methanogenium marinum (ma.ri.num. M.L. adj. marinum marine, indicating the habitat of this species)
The cells are highly irregular coccoids (diameter, 1-1.2 μm) that occur singly and grow by CO2 reduction by using H2 or formate as electron donor.
Cells stain Gram-negative, and cells were lysed by 0.1 g sodium dodecylsulfate per liter or when suspended in distilled water.
Flagella are present, but cells are not motile.
Growth is most rapid with the catabolic substrates H2 plus CO2.
Methanol, ethanol, 1- or 2-propanol, 1- or 2-butanol and trimethylamine are not catabolized.
Acetate is required as a carbon source but it is not catabolized.
Thiamine, riboflavin, peptones, and a high concentration of vitamin B12 are required for good growth.
Yeast extract is not required for growth, but it stimulates faster growth.
Sulfide can serve as a sole sulfur source.
The Topt is near 25 °C, and the temperature range for growth is 5–25 °C.
No growth occurs at temperatures above 28 °C.
Cells are halophilic, growing well in the presence of 0.25 to 1.25 M Na+; but no growth occurs at or above 1.35 M Na+.
The pH range is 5.5 to 7.5 with fastest growth at 6.0.
The habitat is permanently cold, sulfate-depleted marine sediments.
The type strain, strain AK-1, was isolated sediments of Skan Bay, Alaska, and deposited into OCM with the accession number 752.
